er 21, 2013
												This is the most begrudging recommendation I've ever given. Gameplay will make absolutely no sense at first. For example, enemies respawn on a timer and will appear literally just after a blind corner. Thus, there will never be an "all-clear", and thus you will find hacking to be a non-option without literal invisibility because most areas have zero hiding spots from the all-seeing armed thugs. If you can handle the repeated trial-and-error, the confusing text, and the dead ends of research (there's research that takes ten minutes to do IRL and costs resources but gives you nothing, you'll only find out which if you check the wiki or waste your time researching them) (and on that matter, research sometimes requires items  that are dropped by random mooks in a black case that blends in with their environment. Seriously?), EVENTUALLY you will find a game that is fun with satisfying weaponry and, near the end, wonderful and powerful skills. Most importantly, you can get one that kills and enemy and teleports you straight onto them so you can murder and teabag in one fell swoop.But there's just so many bad aspects to the game. I can't say it should be bought for full price. Especially not on Steam where  much better games can be bought for less than ten bucks. I guess I can say it's worth it if you have plenty of spare time and don't know what to do with three bucks this holiday.

												EYE: Divine Cybermancy is one of the most entertaining and ambitious jumbled messes I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing.  Streum On Studio threw whatever they thought might work at the wall, and not everything stuck; the things that did are enjoyable enough to overlook the things that didn't, if you're willing to be patient and learn the game and all its idiosyncrasies.  I highly recommend it for anyone who enjoys Warhammer 40,000, the Deus Ex series, the work of David Lynch, running fast, jumping high, and killing hard.

content:
y 4
												In a nutshell: For Ten bucks, you get a fully fleshed out RPG that plays like a FPS and delights itself in obfuscating the storyline and scenario design to the point of mockery. Oh and your legs will be ok.On paper this looks like someone's dream game in raw form, and to be quite honest once the gameplay clicks, it's actually a rather enjoyable experience. Don't get me wrong, you'll be stumbling through the dark on this one and eventually you'll give up making any sense that this game's plot has (and some mechanics and Scenarios). However, this is the first time in a LONG time I've "beaten" (I think?) a game and wanted to go again immediatley after. This is a game where you can get killed by a door hacking you, your legs will inexplicably be the only limbs that need maintenance (and will be OK for the most part), and for some reason you end up killing your Mentor. It makes no sense half the time and it's oddly delightful in that way.It helps that the gunplay is still rather satisfying (despite being somewhat dated). On top of just shooting all the things, your character has all of these cool Deus-ex-ey cyber upgrades, weird psychic powers, and Ghost in the Shell style hacker-possessions, which are all legitimate ways to deal with most situations.If there are any other downsides besides it's delight in confusing the heck out of you, it is that while some avenues of approach are rewarding if you pull off, they are often times more trouble than they are worth. Stealth for one, is annoying unless you artificially lower the difficulty by hampering enemy sight and sound radiuses in the options menu.  EDIT 3/27/17: Actually Not really if you invest in it (Cloak, Cyber legs, Cyber Eyes, Motra SMG, and Stregnth/Agilityfrom memory) With some skill you can pop in and out of invisibility nailing soldiers left and right or getting into position to hackHacking is oftentimes tedious and pace killing, and you often will be doing it under fire unless you are constantly checking the menu*. Plus it's useless against Demons Metastreumatic Force.  Finally, Melee is rather inneficient, as you can usually deal with a threat better with guns (and not lose as much blood or energy doing it). Still even with modest investments in any of these will give you a viable build 99% of the time. You can still fight, sneak, or hack your way out, even if it isn't as efficient. It's still a lot of fun*As an aside: For some odd reasion  ventilation shafts are far better protected than Federation Special forces units who have some of the LOWEST cyber stats in the game. EDIT 3/27/17: A couple additional flaws that surfaced, Nothing that makes me regret buying this but good to knowAnother knock against it is that some optional scenarios feel impossible. The most infamous being the New Eden (Wurster Corp, the "Green fog" level early in the game) opening, I had some pretty hefty stealth investments, and despite being cloaked, sneaking around the side sewer, and moving VERY SLOWLY. I was still spotted. There are only two of these that come to mind (The other is the infamous "Dont make waves" one) The rest are difficult but with some foresight are completley doable.The last issue I have with it is that multiplayer over internet is a bit of a pain to set up. LAN is fine but me and a friend have had issues getting it set up. It's doable  but more painful than nessecary.It's flawed and confusing, but scrolling through the reviews, you knew that already. And I haven't even touched stuff like character progresssion mechanics(There's PLENTY of ways to do so), Co-op (64 32 Players*! IN THE MAIN GAME!), alternate endings that give you more OP Psychic abilities, and of course, your legs will be OK.*Whoops! I don't know where I got that first number. Still that is INSANE for a Deus-Ex RPG style campaign.But for a fully fleshed out and oddly compelling RPG? Worth Every Brouzouf.

content:
er 8, 2014
												To be technical, it's an FPSRPG with all the usual flair of stats and cybernetic upgrades, inventory etc.Apart from that it's probably the weirdest game I've played in a while. It doesn't seem to follow any of the usual rules of modern game design and ends up feeling very fresh because of it. But the weirdness is almost certainly going to cause the lowest common denominator hate it because, well, it's not easily accessible.The setting is, as someone put it, a mix of Deus Ex, Warhammer 40k, Stalker and a whole slew of 1980's scifi films. Some of the maps would not look at all out of place in a Blade Runner game, for example.Given how cheap the game is, especially when on sale, I just have to recommend it. Even if you are disappointed, you won't be down too many bucks for it, and I can pretty much guarantee that you've not played anything quite like it before.

content:
ber 21, 2014
												My god, do I have mixed feelings about this game.  It clearly ran out of money half way through its development and it has some unbelievably annoying glitches all throughout.  (I also have some problems with certain parts of the story, but in the interest of not giving spoilers to a very story intensive game I won't bring them up here.)  Still, for as annoying as this games flaws can get, they are completely outshown by the amazing, deep experience this game provides.  With the single best Cyberpunk world I've ever heard of, a fascinating (if flawed) story, and the best gameplay in a serious shooter I've ever experienced, I can only recommend this game to shooter fans and RPG fans alike.  (Oh, did I mention they have a really fun and (mostly) balanced character specialization and weapons system?  'Cause that's really important.)  I think my friend put it best; this game does "tacticool" flawlessly.  Be warned; it's very challenging and it does glitch on occasion.  That said, this is one of the best games I've ever played and one of my favorite of all time.

content:
er 22, 2014
												EYE is a source engine game, meaning you'll find the playstyle reminicent to that of Half Life, Left for Dead, etc. But that's just the tip of the iceberg as far as gameplay goes because on top of being a FPS, this game also has RPG elements. You have stats that benefit your melee damage, accuracy, hacking, run speed, Psychic powers, and so on. On top of that you can spend ludicrous amounts of money to get cyber body modifications or to preform research on artifacts which will boost your stats even higher. At a certain point you will be able to run at ridiculous speeds, turn your foes into a fine red mist with a cybernetic claymore, and backstab helicopters with warhammers.However there are a few places where it, debatibaly, falls short. There are a lot of bugs in the game, not including the ones that you can shoot. Even with an extensive ingame tutorial a lot of gameplay mechanics are somewhat unclear. Every character in the game talks and swears like a grizzled bandit, from actual grizzled bandits to your fellow psychic space illuminati assassin paladins. A karma and rating system that 'somehow' are intregal to gameplay probably. Getting shot in the face so hard that it breaks your legs, you get the idea.The story is an absolute trip, even if you do get the final ending there's a lot that you probably wont grasp. With elements such as alternate/nonexistant timelines, internal conflict in past-present tense, and the psychic force of the universe lashing out in the form of monstrosities in retaliation to rapid cyberascension and the squelching out of other species. I honestly have no idea what's going on and neither will you. Shut up and gain brozouf.

content:
12, 2013
												This game is an interesting one, but it also suffers in some ways.The general design aesthetic of the game is possibly the most compelling feature. Imagine Warhammer 40,000, but with more of an pseudo-oriental theme. In it; katanas, large suits of armour and mystical powers. While these are interesting, sadly, the game suffers in gameplay. It is based on Valve's Source engine, and so, like familiar games such as Counter Strike, the shooting system is very good. The guns are all *fairly* unique, and that is all well and good. However, the fighting is very boring. You basically fight waves of highly unintelligent A.I. which more-or-less throw themselves at you for a long time, chewing up your ammunition in a way that feels like it is being put to waste.I read some other reviews about this game which, to paraphrase, said the game put the player head-first into the deep end. Both in the story, and the class/leveling system, implying, or outright accusing the game of being convoluted and unfriendly to new players. In my opinion, these are nothing but excuses for laziness. I'll talk about the class system, since I don't feel like regurgitating the story (also, since I haven't finished it). The class system is sort of 'dynamic' in that it assesses the way you have attributed  skill points to your character, and then 'labels' it. You gain experience, and upgrade stats. The game also earns you 'Brozoufs' (money), with which to buy special upgrades. Everything is written down. If you don't know what something does, then you more than likely did not read its description. Moreover, if you still feel as though there is too much confusion, the game includes 20+ tutorial videos, and there exist game guides for stuck players. If, dspite this, you still need to complain about the difficulty of the game, then regrettably, you are only asking to be spoonfed.The graphics are pretty dated-looking as well (as a result of its being based on Source Engine, no doubt), and this gives the game an 'outdated sci-fi' appearance, and that's sort of unappealing. But you know, it isn't the end of the world.So, to summarise, the game is quite mediocre in important ways. It is an inexpensive game. If you feel the need to try something mildly original in concept, then I would recommend it, but do not expect something groundbreaking.

Highly recommended to all shooter and RPG fans who don't mind something a little rough around the edges, or hard to understand.

content:
13, 2015
												What is E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy?Well that's the million dollar question, isn't it?I don't think it would be possible to fully describe this game in one go, nor would it do the experience that is EYE any kind of justice. Instead, here are a few vignettes and examples of the insanity in store for you.-As you may know by now, you don't create your character with anything as mundane as stat points or sliders. Instead you select three genetic modifiers from a pool of eight or so that randomly affect certain stats in certain ways. What do any of these stats actually do? Stop asking questions and resequence your Tipherath.- The second line of dialogue will you will encounter in the game is the line "I know that I killed my mentor, and yet I am not his murderer." Deep and introspective? Overly pretentious? Poor translation? No way to know for sure. This line essentially sets the dialogue's tone for the rest of the entire game.- You work for an organization called E.Y.E. (abbreviation unknown), which in turn works for an organization called the Secreta Secratorum, a secret society of secrets so secret that absolutely everyone in the game universe knows it exists. In addition, you belong to a subfaction of EYE known as the Culter Dei, which is in an internal war with the other subfaction, the Jiang Shai Di. The Jiangs dress up like post-apocalyptic cyber-samurai, while the culters all look like Space Marine Chaplains from Warhammer 40k. Aside from this, absolutely nothing is known about the two subfactions.- The time period the game takes place in is hard to describe beyond just "Da Future". It states that the current year is 15, but in another area it shows the date as Year 0.100. Apparently the year number reset sometime during the 2300's, but it also describes that in the game's history, humanity began using Psychic soldiers in 1890 and Psykers became part of the civilian public in 1970. Also, you happen to be trapped in a non-linear time loop, but you'll figure that out later.- The in-game currency is something called Brouzouf, or Brouzoufs (both instances are described as being plural). The strange thing is, unlike other games, this currency is never seen in physical form. There are no loose brouzouf that you can pick up off the ground, no ancient treasure caches of the stuff, no credit chits or loose bills. In addition to being rewarded with it from quests, you also magically gain it every time you kill something. You don't have to loot them, it just appears in your... bank account I guess?- There is a sword called the Damocles which causes anything it strikes to violently explode into little chunks, limbs, and a thick red mist. Why it does this is never explained, or at least if it is, I cannot find it. There is an achievement you can acquire with it by decapitating someone with it. Seeing as they essentially vaporize after you hit them with it, I am not sure exactly how you get it or how I even got it in the first place.- Sometimes you will kill homeless people, politicians, caring fathers, or soccer players. You never know when this is going to happen, but it will, and there really isn't anything you can do about it.- When you hack something and fail, there is a chance that you will be counter-hacked. Either your head will explode, killing you, or your HUD will be disabled and replaced with a laughing smiley face. If your HUD gets scrambled, you then have to hack yourself in order to cure it, which can also have lethal consequences. What kind of sinister machines can do this to you? Doors. Environmental controls. Ventilation systems. ATMs.- There is a sequence in which a bandit stops fighting you and spontaneously tells you his life story and how miserable he is. If you off-handedly remark that if you were him, you'd kill yourself, then he will drop the conversation, pause for a moment, and then casually stroll into a nearby mining laser. You will get an achievement for this.- "My legs are okay." Hell, I was crippled? I didn't even notice. Wait, but being crippled is also a lethal wound. So I was crippled, but I wasn't crippled?All that and much more. EYE is not a game, it is an experience, and love it or hate it, there's nothing else quite like it. The funny thing is, for all its strangeness, the gameplay is solid and the RPG elements mix with the FPS elements better than in almost any other game I have ever played. The guns have serious kick and you can hear the bullets ricochet off your armor. For a game made by only twelve people, EYE is nothing if not an accomplishment, even if its only accomplishment is being completely and utterly incomprehensible. And it's only ten bucks when its NOT on sale. E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy gets my recommendation.

content:
r 21, 2016
												Unique game, greatly deserving of a sequel. Quite dated by today, but it's so cheap & fun that it's still worth playing. Nonsensical story, but the wackiness of everything provides all the entertainment you need. Multiple different ways to play the game. Focus on melee combat, ranged gun combat, hacking & psychic powers & combat, or a mess of all of them together. You really feel like a giant super cyborg cultist soldier, where you can be so heavy in armor and metal body augmentations that simply stepping off of the sidewalk can cause the earth to shake.In my opinion, the game is a gem, maybe not a diamond of course, but a decent, unique gem. It's a shame it isn't super popular as the multiplayer is really cool too, with almost a sort of MMO-esque element to it. The best thing that could happen to this game would probably be either the community suddenly re-gaining popularity, or a sequel be made with modern textures and engine tweaks.

content:
er 6, 2016
												It's not bad game, and I noticed on certain sales this game was like ~$1. It is worth much more than $1 for what it provides, with that being said it isn't perfect. It feels very much like an old school game, no hand holding, no checkpoints, you go through a level and you complete it in one "go". It has an ambigious and kind of meta storyline, which is fine, but this game feels...I don't know if this is the right word, but unpolished? If they made a sequel that was more polished it would be an amazing AAA game. I give props to the crew who made this game, I heard it was a very small group and given that fact it is a pretty solid game. As you level up, trying to get certain items, researches, tech and spells can get very grindy. Once you play through the game a few times it feels kind of short, especially when you learn the "shortcuts" in each mission where you can skip most objectives. If they made it so there were more twists and turns in dialogue and actions (not too much but some more), more variety in endings and missions, and put in more customizability to guns/spells/tech/hacking, it could be amazing. I hope they make a sequel, even if it is only a spiritual successor (seeing as...well you will know what the ending(s) are when you play it and understand why I say it would have to be a spiritual successor)

content:
ber 15, 2014
												Freakily addictive for a game that's wierd as all hell. There's nothing to compare it to, because there's nothing that it's like.It looks Warhammer 40k-ish, but plays a lot closer to Deus Ex. The story is what you'd get if Tolstoi had just finished reading the Bourne series, if it was set in the Fallout universe, and he'd been mainlining LSD the whole way. I've played the game twice through, and I'm still trying to work out WTF is going on... but in a really good way... was I dreaming? Hallucinating? Jacked into the Matrix?! Also, WTH hasn't my character put his pistol in his mouth just to make it all stop, please, mommy!The graphics are pretty reasonable, but the sound can get a bit repetitive and the voice-acting is... well... none of it's in English, so I've got no idea whether it's "good but intentionally odd" or just badly done. My only real complaint is that very little is explained. Don't even bother with the tutorials, they're utterly useless. Your best bet is to work it out yourself with some online research to give you a boost.All in all, it's totally worth the price if you're looking for a fairly competent shooter with substantial RPG elements, and a massive dose of WTF that will leave you scratching your head for ages.

content:
ry 13, 2014
As a wandering Space Illuminati Knight Samurai Magician Predator-alien with amnesia you find yourself questioning your role in the Space Illuminati and how the other faction of Space Illuminati Kung-Fu Samurai Sorcerer Ninjas intertwine with your destiny, as a man who writes his own destiny in the neon golden blood of the Space Illuminati temple he lives in, which he calls his soul.E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is a FPS/RPG most comparable to Deus Ex gameplay mixed with Source engine physics, Warhammer 40K aesthetics and a story that's meant to be as confusing as possible.The story revolves around power struggles. Between governments and rebel organizations, between different factions in the same organization, between members within the same faction, and ultimately power struggles within individuals. There are multiple endings and the player has a choice in what factions to side with or betray as well as how they want to accomplish the tasks they've been given. The gameplay is a mix between an FPS and an RPG. You have stats and classes but how well you can point a gun still determines whether you will hit or miss. Your stats affect everything from your ability to use weapons to how prone to hallucinations your character is. It's likely you will be overrun by the amount of stats the game throws at you. You character has weapon/item unlocks, armor types, robotic implants, research, cybernetic upgrades, stats, and semi-permanent debuffs to deal with. Because each of these affects other stats in one of 4 different ways. using a guide isn't a shameful thing in this game when it comes to understanding mechanics.One the FPS side of things it's pretty satisfying and in-depth too. There are keys to lean your character left/right, and they are used often. The guns are also satisfying, whether they're the default ones or higher tiered unlocks. Admittedly all of the guns are crazy accurate, even with a fairly low accuracy stat. Firing in bursts will keep most guns at a near sniper rifle accuracy due to this. Movement can be anywhere from ponderously slow to Arena FPS fast depending upon your equipment weight and your speed, with jump height ranging from a measly little hop to a 4 story leap. Psi powers are the only other thing to talk about and they keep with the weird over the top action by allowing you to literally make enemies explode into red mist before teleporting to their location or just letting a werewolf explode out of their chest and eat their friends.Overall, the game feels like a neon colored, futuristic Bruce Lee movie with robots, demons, robot-demons, afros, garbled English, confusing choose-your-own-adventure book plots ripe with betrayal, and werewolves. Considering it's often below the $5 mark how can you pass that up?

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
er 28, 2015
												E.Y.E. is a hybrid RPG-FPS that tries to re-capture the feeling of Deus Ex using the Source engine and WH40k aesthetics. Does it work though? Partially. The stealth aspect is heavily nerfed in comparison to Deus Ex and most of the time you have to brute-force your way in, but still the game delivers what made Deus Ex good - freedom of approaching your objectives and battles. Add a layer of upgrades, customizability and good weapon selection and you have a rather solid gameplay. But E.Y.E. is not an easy game. It will take at least 2-3 failed attempts to understand how to play it properly. Even with the cheat sheets, it's very easy to misunderstand basic concepts and utilities role. The difficulty ramps up very quickly and by 3rd level it's very easy to get overwhelmed if you're inexeprienced. But once you master the system, the game delivers an amazing experience in terms of many builds you can use. The three main systems - guns, hacking and spells can be used seprately or merged and more often you'll find yourself trying to find a fun build that is in line with your playstyle rather than making a jack-of-all character.On the narrative side, E.Y.E.'s broken English and dialogue choices that range from a calm responses to psychotic threats of violence certain give the game a really weird flavour to it. Some of the messages you get in game "You gain Brouzouf", "My legs are OK" and "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T! Ultra-failed attack!" have become loved by the E.Y.E. community to the point that no discussion is complete without copious amount of Brozouf, checking your legs and making sure your attacks are not Ultra-failed. There is a story hidden behind that facade of poorly translated writing, but it takes a little bit to get to it. It feels more like a forgein film than anything in that manner - it's rough around the edges but ultimately it's enjoyable after watching it twice.It's really hard to describe E.Y.E. - what started out as a clunky, buggy mess of a game with some patching and community turned into one of the "Must-played" cult games. E.Y.E. is an experience. A wonderful experience in the most psychodelic gaming trip you can ever imagine.I recommend it.

content:
28, 2015
												Disappointing. Imagine a stoned Russian telling you a story mixing up many of your favorite sci-fi tropes. Elements from Alien, Deus Ex, Stalker, Doom, Roadside Picnic, and Half-Life thrown in. Sounds great and weird, right? Sadly, it's not.The game consists of running through vast empty levels of dark brown and fog, instantly populated with waves of respawning enemies that will headshot you from across the map, or rain fiery death on you before you can turn around. And that's AFTER you crank both the difficulty and respawn rates down. Gameplay for every level is either "run over here", or "run over here and kill mobs". The game has many elements thrown in - there's 2 or 3 stat systems (all poorly explained, all seeming to do very little), half of a vendor system (you can buy but not sell), psychic powers, and hacking. Great ideas, but not executed well.The game is built on the aging Source engine. It runs more or less fine, it's just not worth it. I really wanted to like this one. Couldn't.

												11/10 GOAT Instant top5 would infinitely play again. It's like Xenogears' kind of lore meets S.T.A.L.K.E.R.'s gameplay AND MANAGES TO IMPROVES BOTH. A truly versatile game with infinite replay possibilities and coherent difficulty. Awesome atmosphere, great immersion, sweet gameplay... I could go on, but you get the point. Also, multiplayer experience is beautifully integrated with single player (back in 2009 you AAA ♥♥♥♥♥es) and still has an active community.The learning curve is quite steep, but the in-game tutorials (optional) and interwebz help will serve you more than enough. Don't let it stop you from enjoying this masterpiece.The only cons are (i) occasional bugs, (ii) weird 'saving' system (ALWAYS go to Temple HQ before quitting), (iii) occasional "oops I attacked a major NPC in a key moment and have to restart mission", (iv) the steep learning curve and (v) occasional grammar problems (understandable for a non-english team). But really, it's nothing. Everything else in the game makes up for that. Specially if you consider how small the team was and that it's not an AAA release.And seriously, it's dirt cheap. What are you waiting for?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2015
												The best way to look at a game like EYE: Divine Cybermancy is through the lens of a person who has not played any other game. Ever. Why? Because it doesn't make any sense. The game deviates so much from the norm, that it would be impossible to compare it to any other game. It isn't really an FPS, nor an RPG, but it has some of both. The story is... satisfactory. It is one of the only games I've played where it hurt to follow the story, but this was only because of my previous experiences with games. Through a lens of a person who hasn't played a game before, the story is fantastic and deep. The rest is average. Playing with other people is semi-fun, servers are semi-populated, and the graphics are semi-good. My legs are okay.So why is this a positive review? Well, first and foremost, I had to change my perspective for it. Not many games made me do that, but EYE: Divine Cybermancy did. Not that it was a good shift, nor a bad shift, but it was a shift. Next, there was little room for buyer's remorse from my dislikes. I got it for only $0.99, cheaper than chips (about half as much where I live), so value wise, it is great.It is unpolished, has an overly complex story with little explanation, and most of the mechanics are left unexplained, but it wasn't BAD. In fact, it was an interesting game, that not only forced me to change the way I saw stories in games, but was a great value at the same time. For $9.99, the shift in perspective is not worth the price, but for $0.99, it very much is. 7/10

content:
17, 2015
												To say E.Y.E. is an excellent game would be a lie. It's an independant game, and it has it's flaws. The most noticable is it's badly trasnlated English, which makes the already confusing story even harder to initally understand. Aside from that, the other problem is some animation problems, making the characters move around in odd ways. Finally is the various glitches that come up during online play such as saves being corrupted and skipping levels entirely. Pass all of this, comes an expansive world full of exploration and deep lore that with ability to be expanded on even further. The gun play is exremely solid, and while some items are not great choices, most guns are and it makes for interesting and dynamic class specializations. The melee is fair enough, though there is something to be desired when playing a ninja-like monk. The PSI powers are satisfying to use and the way the games handles hacking is challenging but fun. The RPG-like skill points let you specialze  in things like PSI or gunplay or melee and make each new character unique. I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of RPGs, it's a unique experience that hasn't been matched by much other games.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2015
												Its great, its RPG elements are pretty deep, almost having a Fallout-ish feel to them. It has mechanics from Deus Ex, like its Cyber Tech and Hacking elements.  Another thing it takes from popular RPGs is its inventory system. You have a limited amount of space, so you cant just carry everything around.Character creation is not very big, it doesn't let you create the physical appearance of your character, but its not needed, because you never see his face. You choose 3 genes to splice together to make your character, each one having a positive and negative effects on your different stats.It has a speech system not unlike the AAA RPG franchises. It consists of choosing dialogue options and seeing what they have to say about it.  If you anger a character, he might get annoyed with you and tell you to shove off, or even attack the player.I haven't played it all that much, but with my time spent in Skyrim, Dragon Age, Mass Effect, and Fallout, I know i'm gonna love this game. I highly suggest checking it out.

content:
26, 2015
												E.Y.E. is unlike anything you will ever play.Let me start out by saying this game is VERY confusing, even with tutorials you will still be lost. It took me quite awhile to understand the basics of the game. Any ailiments you encounter remember to press C, it is a life saver.The game is set in a futuristic cyberpunk world, with some very impressive levels, Great care and love was put into this games setting. Half of the time playing I would set there being in awe, the city levels in particular are gorgeous.The gameplay itself is where the game really shines, nothing is more satisfying than cutting an enemy with a sword only for them to explode into pieces. Any enemy you killed gains you brouzoufs, which can be used for different upgrades or can be used for research to increase your stats.One of my main gripe is the hacking part of the game, nothing about it was enjoyable which can lead to some frustrating encounters. If you failing hacking your character can be killed, so you have to watch your hp all the time. If you can look past some of it's problem, you've got a real hidden gem on your hands. There's no other game like this out there.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
23, 2014
												You gain Brouzouf.E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is a cyberpunk FPS/RPG/Thing where you play as a Warhammer esque cyber-man-soldier-ninja-samurai-sorcerer-guy who is tasked to save the entire universe from an otherworldly plague known as the "I dont even ♥♥♥♥ing know". In the game, a bunch of these similar cyber fellows give you quests that you'll have to solve by either killing everything that stands in your way or sneaking past them, except that the sneaking isn't actually even working so you'll just have to shoot everything. The game even gives you an option to disable enemy spawning so you wont actually even have to do anything, i'm pretty sure you'll even get an achievement for that. You also get granted with a hacking system which works a bit like rock/paper/scizzors on crack, it's really hard to explain but i wont even try to. Let's just say i've heard rumours of people getting killed by doors they have tried to hack.I seriously dont know how to write a review about this game, i've been trying to do so for a very long time but whenever i start doing it, it just ends up getting deleted. This probably happens becouse describing the game is extremely difficult, one could easily say it's a "Deus Ex'ish game with 4-player coop" but that's not really even close to what it actually is.One thing you probably notice is how the game suffers from the Human Revolution syndrome, meaning that everything is presented in an extremely orange/brown way. The game runs on Valve's source engine and as such looks pretty good, although it has some pretty clunky animations.So, i'll try and write it as objectively as possible and tell you what the game is like, i hope that gives you some info on whetever you want to make a purchase or not.A silly thing one might also notice is how the game gives you the regular bad guys to shoot at first but then all the sudden decides that you now need to kill demons and xenomorphs from other dimensions, it makes absolutely no sense but is pretty hilarious to look at.After writing this so called review i scrambled all the parts in it so it would make the least amount of sense possible, that's probably exactly what the developers of this game tried to do and since they succeeded so exceptionally well i think mimicing is suitable.So what makes E.Y.E so weird then? Well the dialogue is one such thing, one questgiver actually tells you that nothing makes any sense and that there isn't a point to anything, and that you dont even actually exist. Some of the other dialogue can just be people swearing a lot, it's really strange and doesn't fit the game whatsoever.So in the end, did i like the game? Yes, no? No. Yes, yes i did. It's a strange one, it has some really bad design decisions and flat out stupid stuff in it but is very entertaining nevertheless. Also the price they are asking for it during sales is so ridiculously low that you might as well just get it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2013
												E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy puts you in a dystopian future where the all-controlling Federation is being overthrown by the Secreta Orginization. You play an agent of E.Y.E, a private army which fights for the Secreta, while fighting a civil war between themselves.The story is quite interesting and inspiring, but the dialogue isn't voiced, and when anything is spoken, it's spoken in a weird sims-gibberish language. However, character choices do affect the missions, such as choosing to shoot up a bar, or calmly speak with the owner. You can help your fellow E.Y.E agents, or choose to abandon them and do the mission solo. The world fits the tone of the story well, putting you in cities, slums, colonies, factories, other planets, and sewers. However, there aren't enough NPC's. The world feels empty, just you and bad guys. There are no civilians to avoid, no merchants hiding in corners to sell you a boost. Gameplay is very smooth, and has several tutorials in case you didn't understand some of the more advanced mechanics. One can build their character with a specific endgame in mind, or they can continue and simply put points into whatever they want, which makes progression very simple to manage. The inventory management is clunky, and simply hindering, limiting your full potential, but it could have been worse. Campaign missions are ridiculously long and easy, whereas secondary missions seem to be harder and shorter. Adjusting the difficulty on the secondary missions changed it into a fun and exiciting challenge. The general feel of the game is exhilarating, fighting monsters, looters, cops, and watching their bodies fall to the side, explode, or watch their limbs get sliced off. There hasn't been an end to the content, and even if I do reach level 50+, there are still more weapons to unlock and purchase. I haven't gotten all the cybertech upgrades, or psi powers, or finished all the research. This game simply never ends, you choose where to stop.Gameplay - 10/10Story - 7/10World/Environment - 9/10Overall - 9/10 I would definently reccomend buying this game and playing it with a few friends.I hope there will be an E.Y.E 2, I would back it on kickstarter if there would be! I am looking forward to seeing more games by Streum Studios as well.

content:
y 26, 2016
												Intricate and ridiculous, EYE has earned every wise word spoken for it. It may also subvert every wise word spoken against it, even mine. EYE is not a success, and it is not always fun. On optimized systems you can expect protracted load times and glaring proofs of the Source engine's age. Much is amateurish; little thought seems to have gone into refreshing whatever was borrowed from Source assets (namely physics and other special effects. In EYE, your hand is the Gravity Gun). And you may be unimpressed by the character models, and sickened by the abrasive sound effects and voices, and the ugliest browns and greens you've ever seen.You will be tested. Here EYE hints that some of its flaws are not accidental, that they fit into a larger scheme. Perhaps you have played Pathologic, or STALKER, that other difficult game about acronyms. You have a suite of weapons with no clear utility and you will have to work for an hour to figure out which ones are useful. You have all sorts of abilities, but they are also spotty, and finding a way to even use them will take you at least one minute. You begin play with a rough idea that you can improve" by spending resources on various things, some of them new weapons, some of them abstract representations of the things you can do. You may or may not figure out a plot; you may or may not sort out an efficient way to become better using one of two unexplained single-player game modes, or to become functionally better (as in more skilled) using the insane multi-player game mode. When a game puts up one kind of road block, who would I be to assume its other obstacles are accidental? I would have to be some kind of games journalist. I know that I am no kind of games journalist, because all deep questions recede as soon as I do the thing EYE most enthusiastically invites you to do: commit thoughtless virtual murder using a toolkit too large for my IRL kitchen. I blew up a man with a handgun called The Bear Killer today. I then hacked a computer in his friend's brain and compelled his friend to kill their remaining friends. I then summoned three psychic clones of myself to kill the confused survivor. Some mutants came, and I murdered them, too. EYE: Divine Cybermancy gives you all of these gifts, but it taxes you. Somehow, this feels thematic: when it is as easy as Hell to disappear a million mutant men with a single shotgun, the real antagonist might be getting *into* it in the first place. I sense deep genius, and complex fun. EYE makes you compromise for pleasure. When you ask why it might, you see that it wants you to think - but only for as long as it takes to reload.

er 25, 2011
												This game is definitely not the best mix of First Person Shooter and Role Playing Game out in this catalogue: The enemy AI is a bit too smart at times, making the game unnecessarily difficult, and you're gonna need to read a very extensive tutorial file in order to get any heads or tails of the interface and its intricacies. But if you manage to get beyond that, you will find a game that is ambitious, but knows what its doing. The story is non-linear, spiritual and at times a bit mindscrewy, with interesting dialogue and intriguing characters which you can't actually read with a mere shallow look, and the gameplay does the job well. If you like bleak, gritty cyberpunk games, give it a try, it will not disappoint you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 16, 2015
 Positive + Akin to games such as System Shock 2, Deus Ex, and other FPS/RPG hybrids, E.Y.E.: Divine Cybermancy allows you to customise your character how you want, with a wide variety of cybernetic implants to choose from, and research to further power yourself up. Combined with solid gunplay (though the enemy AI may tend to idle around quite often and not get behind any sort of cover) makes the gameplay department quite enjoyable for the most part+ Utilising the Source Engine, the game may not excel in the graphical department, but it does manage to present a well-detailed environment, combining cyberpunk elements and a dark tone; topped off with great physics that complement the gameplay+ Adding onto the atmosphere, the music is certainly eerie and matches the quality of the visual aesthetic. This is probably one of the best aspects of the game. Negative - The biggest negative here is the games interface. Not only does it have a steep learning curve, but the supplied tutorials are lacking and don’t explain all of the necessary elements of the game very well. While I was able to get used to it in the end, there’s no denying that the interface makes it very hard to get immersed into the game due to how unintuitive and clunky it is- While the level design may be commended for being more open and spacious than the average linear FPS, the size of some of the levels actually ends up hurting the experience. Though I may have never gotten lost, it’s not very exciting travelling through the environments at a slow pace, combined with the fact that there is no real reward or gratification from exploring the empty levels; adding more secrets and hidden side quests would have made exploration much more appealing- One of the minor complaints of the RPG elements the game has is the fact that you will need to do a lot of grinding if you want to be able to buy/upgrade implants or weapons. You don’t need to upgrade or buy anything to beat the main story, but it’s unfortunate that you are required to grind for hours just to buy weapons that you may want to use, which means you’ll be stuck with the base equipment that you have in your starting armoury unless you go out of your way to grind for better ones- Lastly, the story is very poorly presented and convoluted; the dialogue especially is a pain to read through (which may unfortunately be due to poor translation). Though the game may have multiple endings, none of them feel complete or give a satisfying conclusion to the overall weak plot. The story barely strings together fully and feels like it’s tacked on rather than integrated well with the gameplay. The game is an okay length at 6 ½ hours (Normal difficulty), but there are only about 11 or so levels to progress through; however, playing the game in co-op could make the experience more fun. Verdict “A game marred by some visibly weak elements, E.Y.E.: Divine Cybermancy has both its high and low points. With a bit more polish, this game could’ve been truly amazing, but it sadly falls a little short. Though if you are looking for a good and cheap co-op FPS (and a decent single-player experience), this will certainly entertain you for a few hours.” 7/10 TJBs

content:
y 13, 2014
												I'm going to preface this review saying that for a game made by 10 people and a half-finished HL2 mod it is a really neat game. It has great combat and story. The XP system has a lot of potential.Unfortunately, the save system is BROKEN. BROKEN. It only saves after (some) major missions, so if you save and quit halfway through a mission your XP is in tact but you have to start from the start of the mission the next time you play. Keep in mind that the missions are about and hour and fifteen minutes each. It's a real grind to play. If they had a simple quicksave or manual save the game would be great. Also note that the maps are HUGE for sourcemod. They aren't huge in a good way though. Sprint eats up your power and there is a lot inbetween objectives. Reinforcements sometimes respawn right behind you and score a quick kill, taking away a ressucitator, which take a lot of work to get. It's like I'm playing terrorist hunt on Rainbow Six 3:Raven Shield all over again.

content:
er 21, 2013
												Once in every generation a game defies classification, no matter how hard you try.E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is a game you have not played before, it is as unique as it is flawed.Imagine if you will that you crossed an FPS, a resource strategy game and an RPG and wrapped it into the cyber-fantasy setting.  E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is just that, a unique genre-blend that exceeds expectation in game design while unfortunately failing at presentation (spectacularly).E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy isn't a pretty game by an stretch of the imagination, its washed out low resolution textures, low polygon count, completely asinine UI, non-existant soundtrack, terrible voice-acting and translation will make many recoil in disgust. Yet, it succeeds where many other games do not by providing a gameplay experience so unique and well-crafted that all these flaws can be forgiven. The blend of cybernetic warfare, stealth, first-person shooting and resource management provide for untold hours of replayability. Add on top of that multiplayer co-op and the game becomes a fantastic title well worth your time.There is something incredibly visceral about running into battle, blocking bullets as they impact your swords, landing in a cloud of dust to unleash a power-attack at your helpless foes. Similarly, the same scenario can be played by hiding behind a wall and hacking the one of the troops, taking over his implants and making him shoot his own soldiers. Or perhaps, if you prefer the ranged alternative, unleashing a torrent of projectiles from your minigun while summoning the demons of hell with your psionic powers, warping the frail minds of your opponents as they collapse in their own excrement.E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy allows for all this, and more.The haunted atmosphere fits perfectly with its setting and while it might not be the prettiest of games, it certainly is consistent in art-direction. Everything you encounter will be gritty, run down and punk, yet also etheral and dream-like. The world is empty and hollow, and it fits the theme incredibly well. As your body suffers, your mind does as well and you should be prepared to deal with the consequences. Sanity is a rare commodity in this universe.E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy offers an experience like no other, it is gritty, it is creative, it is unforgiving, and you will love it.-------Read more video game news, reviews and editorials at gatheryourparty.com

												This game have a very unique atmosphere - very scary and mysterious. By the genre it's an FPS with RPG elements, but the thing I like the most about it - is how atmospheric enviroments and all around you is.Though this game not the easiest to understand (I still have no idea what's going on with it's plot), but I have to say - I strongly reccomend to at least try and play demo version to see if you like this type of gameplay. It's scary but without any jumpscares - the whole graphic and sound design is very appealing to me. Visually it borrows heavily from Giger's art for alien environments, and from Blade Runner for city ones - and it works great!E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is very hard to compare to any other game.Warframe is apparently heavily inspired by this game Only Divine Cybermancy doesn't have a $hitty F2P aspect - you buy this game and you get full experience without the need to endlessly grind for resources.

content:
2, 2014
												This game harkens back to the old school action rpg days of the original Deus Ex.  The game boasts decent controls with interesting settings and plenty of intrigue.  This game has a soul and atmosphere that is lost in most modern games.  As a bonus it isn't that pretentious of a game despite it being indie.  This is a good game for people that enjoy more classic fps/rpg hybrids a la Morrowind or the orginal Deus Ex.Pros:Good Atmosphere ( grimdark edgy world with edgy people, but the small things, like the ads scattered around the city, add some semblence of life to it )Semi-Complex RPG elements ( implementation may be a little clunky, but the customization and opportunity it allows the player is always preferred over "streamlined" casual ♥♥♥♥ )Decent Controls ( for an indie game i'm content, though why i can't lean and walk makes me upset, sometimes the world just needs to be diagonal and on the move )Actually has lore ( it's mostly optional and not really shown in the game world, but world building shows care and makes a setting all the more interesting )Cons:Clunky compared to AAA Titles ( no ♥♥♥♥ really )Tutorial videos are boring ( and optional, I probably don't know half the ♥♥♥♥ i can do )Slow beginning ( really off putting for me until i powered through the first segement or two )

content:
ber 26, 2013
												Уникальная игра! Она позволила взглянуть на киберпанк по другому, прочувствовать его. Признаюсь после темного киберпанка E.Y.E., в другие проекты той же направленности не шибко веришь. Действительно интересный сюжет, которые может отпугнуть на первой половине игры, но развязка первой концовки, заставила приоткрыть рот в изумлении. Но есть еще одна проблема связання с сюжетом, что бы понять всю исторю, вам придется последовательно пройти игру 4 раза!!! Да да, именно 4 раза, не у многих хватит терпения. Графически игра выполнена на движке соурса, не чего уж шибко великолепного, но дизайн локаций отличный. Саундтрек тоже вполне не плохой. Геймплейно игра немного странновата, на каждой локации, в которую мы поподем, практически всегда на нас будут переть толпы врагов, от которых придется постояно отстреливатся выполняя определенные задачи, не каждому такое по вкусу придет. Но есть такие уровни которые просто никогда не забудутся! Один из них - это уровень на военной базе с которой потеряна связь и, черт возьми, его атмосфера просто ложит на лопатки недавний Aliens Colonial Marine. Впринципе игра сугубо на любителя, для людей которые не боятся позновать что то новое. Всем другим, которые любят блокбастеры с крутейшей графикой, казуальщиной и одноклеточным геймплеем, не рекомендую приближатся на растояние пушечного выстрела!

This is a good game for people that enjoy more classic fps/rpg hybrids a la Morrowind or the orginal Deus Ex.Pros:Good Atmosphere ( grimdark edgy world with edgy people, but the small things, like the ads scattered around the city, add some semblence of life to it )Semi-Complex RPG elements ( implementation may be a little clunky, but the customization and opportunity it allows the player is always preferred over "streamlined" casual ♥♥♥♥ )Decent Controls ( for an indie game i'm content, though why i can't lean and walk makes me upset, sometimes the world just needs to be diagonal and on the move )Actually has lore ( it's mostly optional and not really shown in the game world, but world building shows care and makes a setting all the more interesting )Cons:Clunky compared to AAA Titles ( no ♥♥♥♥ really )Tutorial videos are boring ( and optional, I probably don't know half the ♥♥♥♥ i can do )Slow beginning ( really off putting for me until i powered through the first segement or two )

er 30, 2012
												Great and kind of unique cyberpunk game, mixture between FPS and cRPG genres on the Source engine. Great artwork (overally - models, textures, maps), atmosphere, interesting story and classic gameplay are big "pro's" of the game. Very fun and gives you at least few ways to complete your tasks (not mentioning you first create your own character, later on you buy upgrades for him like cyber-implants or access to new guns or new "spells" if you go the "PSI" way). The game includes campaign and single missions with randomized objective's and enemy, both of these can be played in the multiplayer (which is great for "farming" \ "grinding"). Limited, but classy gore and one of the best guns ever found in a video game.It might be confusing at the start, but it's a very enjoyable product. It succesfully mixes the elements of the Warhammer 40.000 realities with some other, sometimes more, sometimes less original elements. If You liked Crysis and you don't puke on the first sights of cyberpunk and cRPG - you should enjoy the game all right, because the gameplay is closest to Crysis (using implants like cloak, superstrenght, etc).

content:
er 14, 2015
												Went in expecting Deus Ex, only to find it was more like Dark Souls with guns. Now I like Dark Souls, but at least Dark Souls follows certain rules and conventions. This game is just all over the place. The real 'prepare to die' experience starts here!-Objectives are often vague, and while venturing around a large map trying to figure out how to get to the waypoint feels like a nice touch of exploration, it's ruined by the respawning enemies (see below).-Damage is way too high (even on Easy), and a grenade in a tight corridor is effectively a death sentence.-The fact that enemies respawn means you'll often be attacked from behind just when you thought you'd thoroughly cleared the area. At least you can always run back to the mobile armoury for ammo...-The grammar and tone of the dialogue feels like it was written by a high-schooler who averaged Ds in English.-Can't make heads of tails of the plot. The story beginning with an amnesiac protagonist thrown into the middle of a civil war / political coup (is that what's happening?) doesn't make it much easier. I've heard of 'in media res' but this is ridiculous.-WHY ARE THERE SO MANY ENEMIES, I TURNED THE RESPAWN RATE WAY DOWN, OH GOD THEY'RE ALL OVER ME-Stats and classes are also a little tricky to figure out. I'm sure they do something, but I don't really feel any different after multiple level-ups.-Occasional difficulty telling which doors can and can't be interacted with.-Reloading causes you to waste any unused bullet in the current magazine (WHAT the ACTUAL ♥♥♥♥). Add in the fact that there is no automatic reloading when you run out of bullets and you will choke in almost every single high-pressure situation.-Some odd level geometry causes problems with movement here and there, particularly when moving in and out of vents or past deceptively small-looking bits of rubble/pipe/what-have-you.+Saving up for upgrades and equipment is a nice incentive. You get currency bonuses for high-performance combat (headshots, backstabs, etc), so you get rewarded for not just spraying and praying.+The style of clothing, technology and - in some cases - architecture is pretty cool.+Some levels contain posters of hot girls with guns.+The melee weapons all look really cool, and the ability to defend against projectiles makes them HUGELY useful.+/- what language is everyone speaking and whyMaybe I'm playing this game wrong, but honestly, it just feels bad and unenjoyable to play. 4/10, would not recommend.

content:
ry 27, 2012
												E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is definitely one of the most fun and innovative games I’ve ever played. Set in a futuristic cyber/steampunk world, you play as a member of the secret society called E.Y.E. A special society trained in using psi powers and other high tech gadgets to accomplish their mission.  E.Y.E. is a top notch FPS/RPG game that allows for multiple styles of game play and plenty of character customization. You can go guns blazing, take the stealthy approach or even hack into your enemies and control their every movement. You are also in possession of a huge arsenal that carries machine guns, snipers, mini guns and even grenade launchers. With all these things at your disposal, you know this game has an amazing replay value to it. You can also go co-op with up to 16 players and wreck havoc upon the open world maps. It’s a refreshing and addicting title that I think everyone should pick up.

content:
6, 2012
												E.Y.E is far from perfect. It's weird, obtuse to the point of being frustrating and the dialogue often feels like it's been run through Google translate (Streum On are French, so it probably has). The weirdness is actually one of the things I like about it though. The grammatically flawed text not so much; Streum could definitely benefit from a native English speaker going through all the dialogue and making it less obviously written by someone who isn't.But the weirdness works. E.Y.E comes across like a blend between 40K's Inquisition and one of the evil megacorps of Syndicate; with it's bizarre mix of psionic techno-magery, cyberpunk gadgetry and John Blanche-esque armour suits. It gets compared a lot to a 'fever dream'; and given the developer's stated enjoyment of H.P Lovecraft, this is not a bad comparison. E.Y.E's very openended and that can work against it for some - too much choice, especially with little guidance as to how those choices will affect you in the field, can be off-putting. You do have to read around the little windows and you sometimes have to live with a choice that might not have been exactly what you were expecting. Enemy levels can be a tad overwhelming, too. Freely re-spawning legions of mooks are a pain in the ♥♥♥ when combined with big, dark, labyrinths and vague mission briefs and this can make the side-quests (which are pretty basic; essentially retreads of levels you've completed with different random objectives like Kill X, Fetch Y), feel a touch grindy as you mow down two gangs of mooks only to be set on by two more as you reload and scavenge bullets from the corpses. Steam's recommendation windows are really too small - so, yeah. E.Y.E's interface and tutorials are almost ferociously unfriendly to those of us who've grown accustomed to the hand-holding of more recent RPG / FPS releases. E.Y.E leans more to the school of "Here, work it out for yourself." Which has been one of the big bones of contention about it for many. Purely for clarity; I mean good, old Syndicate, not the shoddy modern FPS with the brand name tacked on. But it still feels fun; the guns work well and slicing and dicing the enemy with your psionic katana and blue-glowy psi-fist is still satisfying (see also the teleporting into other people to make them explode method). Although it's billed as an FPS/RPG, the RPG side of things is mainly a case of what numbers you put up on your character sheet, although there are plot twisty things down the line.Me, I like it. As has been observed, what other game lets you cloak and teleport yourself into the body of an enemy so that they explode?Also, it's cheap. And has trading cards :gordon: Give it a whirl.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2014
												Firstly, the concept is amazing. Kind of like a cross between Warhammer 40K (as has been said before), Blade Runner, Dune, Total Recall, Equilibrium, and probably a few other classics I can't think of right now, with a lot of original - and borrowed, stuff on the surface and underneath, including paranormal phenomena, cyberpunk and genetic body mods, hacking, genetic manipulation for basic skill boosts/affinities, and futuristic Rastafarianism. The quintessential Sci-Fi nerd's game, IMO.There's a money system for investing in physical/cybernetic enhancements and weapons, and research toward the same, all funded by things like bounties, hacking bank computers, and lump-sum mission completion rewards. There's also a skill point-based leveling system with lots of options for specialization, e.g., stealth, brute force, finesse, faster/greater health/recovery, athletics/acrobatics, psychic control/telekinesis, hacking enemy machinery/weapons - even their  brains to do your bidding (but watch out, you may get hacked if they're better than you!), et al.Some say it tries to do too much. I like all of the things it does too much to agree. Granted, the dialogue seems to be poorly translated, but in a far-flung future, a significant change in vernacular isn't inconceivable. I think it adds depth, in that respect. Maybe it was deliberate. There's also a bit of a learning curve due to a clunky tutorial, but creating a couple of throw-away characters while practicing and figuring out what you like isn't at all uncommon.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2014
												Firstly, the concept is amazing. Kind of like a cross between Warhammer 40K (as has been said before), Blade Runner, Dune, Total Recall, Equilibrium, and probably a few other classics I can't think of right now, with a lot of original - and borrowed, stuff on the surface and underneath, including paranormal phenomena, cyberpunk and genetic body mods, hacking, genetic manipulation for basic skill boosts/affinities, and futuristic Rastafarianism. The quintessential Sci-Fi nerd's game, IMO.There's a money system for investing in physical/cybernetic enhancements and weapons, and research toward the same, all funded by things like bounties, hacking bank computers, and lump-sum mission completion rewards. There's also a skill point-based leveling system with lots of options for specialization, e.g., stealth, brute force, finesse, faster/greater health/recovery, athletics/acrobatics, psychic control/telekinesis, hacking enemy machinery/weapons - even their  brains to do your bidding (but watch out, you may get hacked if they're better than you!), et al.Some say it tries to do too much. I like all of the things it does too much to agree. Granted, the dialogue seems to be poorly translated, but in a far-flung future, a significant change in vernacular isn't inconceivable. I think it adds depth, in that respect. Maybe it was deliberate. There's also a bit of a learning curve due to a clunky tutorial, but creating a couple of throw-away characters while practicing and figuring out what you like isn't at all uncommon.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 29, 2014
												Absolutely recommend picking this game up. It's a bit difficult to grasp, but once you get rolling, (and this is all assuming you're a cyberpunk fan) you won't be able to drop it. The eerie and gloomy atmosphere is sure to immerse you completely, the fun, innovative gameplay is bound to keep you constantly searching for new ways to overcome a problem, and if all else fails - the randomly generated missions will always be there for a quick jolt when you're in a race with time.The story is a marvel the likes of which I haven't seen yet. I read a lot of books, I watch a lot of movies, shows, but E.Y.E.'s incredibly complex, multi-dimensional, multi-layered allegorical presentation of consciousness was genuinely one of the greatest experiences of my life. As a matter of fact - I believe that the specific story (which I leave for you to figure out) is in its optimal medium; no book or song could ever transfer the atmosphere the same way this game does. The amount of thought I put into the thematic of the whole game, and the amount of time I spent trying to understand the underlying philosophical problems - both in the game, and transfered into real life - is unprecedented.As many agree, if you're one in favor of immersive, drawn-out, atmospheric surrounding, and if you're a fan of the strange, -AND- an enthusiastic problem-solver, this masterpiece will become one of your favorites, too. The game offers too much of the three for anyone to miss them during gameplay, and is sure to have something for everyone who doesn't play video games just for the pure time-wasting aspect of it, but for the artistic value.And before you decide to opt out, riddle me this - "Are you lost? Or have you been lost since the very beginning?"

4, 2014
												This game is a fantastic work of gameplay and storytelling. While the engine is old, the translation not-so-awesome, and the rate of research drops absolutely silly, the rest of the game is well worth $10 any day. Zipping around the battlefield with fully upgraded cyberlegs and bashing in heads with hammers and swords has never been so much fun. Be sure to play it again for each of 4 different endings and spend hours with others just trying to understand the full plot. Good gunplay and fun map design round out the experience, all of which is much more fun with more people. Hop onto a server hosting anywhere from 2 to 32 players for a crazy time of monster slaying, federation beating, and brouzouf gathering.At $1, this game is a steal. Grab it and play it. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												tl;dr: Good: The level design, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ story if you're the kind that likes to speculate, and weapons not saddled by the need to be "realistic" or even balancedBad: They're not the smartest cops or looters. LOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOONG loading times. The story if the storytelling style isn't something that you can't really appreciateWherever you go, whoever you side with, you will always Brouzouf. This insane first person shooter/RPG hybrid has one of the craziest stories ever written, where the story lapses in and out of coherence and continuity, yet still works very well. The enviroments are amazing and highly inspired, and massive. Quite a feat, especially with source engine. While there is one huge loading screen at the beginning of the huge levels, they are the only ones, there are no loading screens anywhere within a level, in the the massive ones like the Headquarters or Mars. Enemies look great, although their intellegence leaves a bit to be desired. One looter blew his buddy up after shooting him with his shotgun that he was aiming at me. Well, the first one shouldn't have stood in his way anyways. Enemy spawn can be a bit of a pain, too. New Eden has a spot next to some shipping containers that spawns Federal Police whenever you're not facing, even if you're facing away but standing next to the spawn point, they'll spawn. Then shoot you. Secreta help you if they have the dreaded Bear Killer. That would mean you have the demon gun too, though. You do have it, right? Brings up another point: the weapons. Dear God those weapons. A handgun that is an effective anti-air and anti-demon cannon. A minigun good against large groups of squishy Feds, Looters, and beasts, although not the best choice for armored enemies like Interceptors. A shotgun that goes further, so much further, than a sneeze. A katana that blows people up. Even the AK knockoff has an awesome feel for it. An SMG that has two firing modes: Full and Fuller. It all comes from the magical Armory of Holding in the beginning of each level that makes you feel like you're going through a candy store with a "all you can eat" coupon. Some minor complaints. Again the AI. You've probably already know my gripes so no further. Furthering the skill tree involves randomly dropping briefcases, in which those have randomly generated technology dropped, some of them being much rarer than others. You can find S.O.B 13 easy, though if you find Cybernecromancy, go ahead and buy a lottery ticket right after. It can be a pain to unlock weapons and technology because of this. If you play on the lower difficulties, it can also be difficult to gather enough brouzouf, cold hard cash, to fund research, cyberlimbs, PSI abilities, and most importantly: weapons. This is easily remedied by not being a wimp and cranking the difficulty up: Ghost usually has you swimming in cash, particuarly if you unlock the Bear Killer and go Dues Ex Machina and Interceptor hunting with it. The AI I can forgive because the rest of the game carries it, and also because this game gets cheaper than a meal at In-N-Out during sales. The rest of the issues can be remedied or at least fixed with a bandaid by adjusting spawn rates and AI behavior. Overall, I highly recommend this game. It looks a bit dated but the design is great, the guns feel deadly, and it doesn't feel the need to limit the player in case he gets "too strong".

												       Let me tell that you will have a love-hate relationship with this game while playing it. First of all, it has really a really unclear story and poorly translated dialogue plus the narrative is poorly delivered and mostly received through dialogue.Information in this game is also very poorly delivered as the game's tutorials will teach you chicken ♥♥♥♥.The A.I  is a mix of super intelligent and incredibly stupid, here's an example; the A.I  is smart enough to detect a dead body and spot you from a mile away but will often run straight towards you and get shot plus they deal alot of damage and this game can be really hard at times [trust me I played DarkSouls] Besides that, the game has alot of glitches and is repetitive in quite a number of aspects throughout gameplay.  Although it lacks content it makes up for really satistfying gunfights, really fun cyber implants and augments, a really nice art style and soundtrack and good character models. Overall the game ends up being just above average I would recommend this game to anyone who can tolerate a little bad medicine..  [actually alot]     My Rating: 6/10     P.S  If you plan on playing this game you're gonna have to read a quick quide first...

												This game may be seen as a mess at first, and honestly it is, but there's something very special about that seperates it from other FPS games of today. Imagine a universe with a combination of Deus Ex, WH40k, Half Life, and Killzone, mix it up in a blender and you got E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy. This game has so many choices and so many options that it actually seems too complex for the player at first (if buying this game, I'd recommend watching How To's first as the game does not explain each of the features). Don't despair, and press on as this game has wonderful immersion and you will be able to catch on quickly. I almost immediately got addicted and played nearly 9 hours straight. I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves Deus Ex

There is a story (which is a bit confusing, but pretty awesome once you got it)  and an own world with it's punks and metastreunomic forces, but it doesn't really matter that hard cause you play the game to level up your character.Also the shooting mechanics are very fun!A secret tip for fps/rgp players!

content:
y 11, 2014
												I bought it a couple of years ago, played for a few minutes, then gave up... I reinstalled it today because I couldn't remember why did I give up playing it before. Now I remember why: the terribly complicated interface and its tiny writings. If you want to understand what's what, what's not and what's going on, you'll have to do a lot of reading, and I have to say, reading those tiny little letters in a greenish/grayish kind of environment involves a lot of eye strain... Now I realize that the name of the game must be a hint as to what you'll be in for, should you decide to play it. Now the gameplay and combat are alright, if you can look past the dated graphics. Overall, its an OK shooter with some RPG elements, unfortnatelly I cannot tell you more because as I said, the interface drives me crazy and I cannot get myself to like the whole thing because of that. For the price it normally sells (on sale today for 1,99), I'd recommend anyone to give it a try, maybe you won't find the same issues I did, and you'll get to have a nice experience. Good luck.

er 20, 2014
												My hacking attempt had failed and so Rimanah stood there with the Black Crow to my head.  As I waited for him to pull the trigger I realised that he wasn't going to.  He wasn't going to because he was waiting for me.  Why?  Because he wasn't there to begin with.  I was holding the Black Crow.  I and I alone.  I lower the gun from my temple and slowly stand.  The wind blows with force now, carrying the stench of half remembered crimes.  I put the Black Crow away and see that my legs are Ok.  So I draw the Damocles and, with a force that sunders the ground beneath my feet, hurl myself a titan's span into the grinning face of the Deuse Ex.  Why?  Because my hacking attempt had failed.  My hacking attempt failed because you can't hack a dream.

												E.Y.E. is a difficult game.Not only in terms of unforgiving gameplay, but also in terms of game quality.On one hand it amazes and revolutionizes the fps genre with such an incredible and deep gameplay that is should baffle even deus ex players what this game pulls of there.On the other hand the game can be very bugging, frustrating and partially random; this is clearly a game for hardcore fps/rpg players, and it is without any doubt the hardest fps I ever played in my whole life.If I would need to describe the gameplay, I would say it is a fps/rpg grindgame. There is a story (which is a bit confusing, but pretty awesome once you got it)  and an own world with it's punks and metastreunomic forces, but it doesn't really matter that hard cause you play the game to level up your character.Also the shooting mechanics are very fun!A secret tip for fps/rgp players!

er 20, 2014
												My hacking attempt had failed and so Rimanah stood there with the Black Crow to my head.  As I waited for him to pull the trigger I realised that he wasn't going to.  He wasn't going to because he was waiting for me.  Why?  Because he wasn't there to begin with.  I was holding the Black Crow.  I and I alone.  I lower the gun from my temple and slowly stand.  The wind blows with force now, carrying the stench of half remembered crimes.  I put the Black Crow away and see that my legs are Ok.  So I draw the Damocles and, with a force that sunders the ground beneath my feet, hurl myself a titan's span into the grinning face of the Deuse Ex.  Why?  Because my hacking attempt had failed.  My hacking attempt failed because you can't hack a dream.

content:
y 11, 2014
												I bought it a couple of years ago, played for a few minutes, then gave up... I reinstalled it today because I couldn't remember why did I give up playing it before. Now I remember why: the terribly complicated interface and its tiny writings. If you want to understand what's what, what's not and what's going on, you'll have to do a lot of reading, and I have to say, reading those tiny little letters in a greenish/grayish kind of environment involves a lot of eye strain... Now I realize that the name of the game must be a hint as to what you'll be in for, should you decide to play it. Now the gameplay and combat are alright, if you can look past the dated graphics. Overall, its an OK shooter with some RPG elements, unfortnatelly I cannot tell you more because as I said, the interface drives me crazy and I cannot get myself to like the whole thing because of that. For the price it normally sells (on sale today for 1,99), I'd recommend anyone to give it a try, maybe you won't find the same issues I did, and you'll get to have a nice experience. Good luck.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2015
												This game is definitely a nice addition to any shooter fan's library. Sure, it has its problems here and there, and it can be frustating at times, but all the positives of this game far overshadow that. It's a true RPS, giving you in-depth character customization, and a unique and interesting room-and-weight-based inventory system that really causes you to think of what you do and do not need to bring with you on your journey. Add to that the freedom to play how you like, the amazing spells, the mix of Psychic and Cybernetics, the cool creatures and characters, and the uniquely engaging research system, as well as all the other content this game brings. You'll be spending more time in E.Y.E. than you'd probably expect upon first look. Cyberpunk games are few and far between, and it's even harder to find ones that are fun, luckily this one helps the genre out instead of hurting it. When you encounter the Deus Ex for the first time, E.Y.E.'s awesome reference to DOOM's monstrous Cyberdemon, you'll truly realize the scope of this great shooter.

content:
er 21, 2014
												Firstly, the concept is amazing. Kind of like a cross between Warhammer 40K (as has been said before), Blade Runner, Dune, Total Recall, Equilibrium, and probably a few other classics I can't think of right now, with a lot of original - and borrowed, stuff on the surface and underneath, including paranormal phenomena, cyberpunk and genetic body mods, hacking, genetic manipulation for basic skill boosts/affinities, and futuristic Rastafarianism. The quintessential Sci-Fi nerd's game, IMO.There's a money system for investing in physical/cybernetic enhancements and weapons, and research toward the same, all funded by things like bounties, hacking bank computers, and lump-sum mission completion rewards. There's also a skill point-based leveling system with lots of options for specialization, e.g., stealth, brute force, finesse, faster/greater health/recovery, athletics/acrobatics, psychic control/telekinesis, hacking enemy machinery/weapons - even their  brains to do your bidding (but watch out, you may get hacked if they're better than you!), et al.Some say it tries to do too much. I like all of the things it does too much to agree. Granted, the dialogue seems to be poorly translated, but in a far-flung future, a significant change in vernacular isn't inconceivable. I think it adds depth, in that respect. Maybe it was deliberate. There's also a bit of a learning curve due to a clunky tutorial, but creating a couple of throw-away characters while practicing and figuring out what you like isn't at all uncommon.

I can use a sword, pistol, assault rifle, or psychic powers to kill my enemies.  I gain levels.  I play a bizarre hacking mini-game to take control of doors and turrets.  I am a jedi/samurai/sharpshooter/cyborg with amnesia.  Also, E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is probably the coolest trio of nonsense words ever.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves Deus Ex
